text: And Isaac trembled very exceedingly , and said, Who? where is he that hath taken venison, and brought it me, and I have eaten of all before thou camest, and have blessed him? yea, and he shall be blessed.
text_kjv: And Isaac trembled very exceedingly , and said, Who? where is he that hath taken venison, and brought it me, and I have eaten of all before thou camest, and have blessed him? yea, and he shall be blessed.
text_niv: Isaac trembled violently and said, “Who was it, then, that hunted game and brought it to me? I ate it just before you came and I blessed him—and indeed he will be blessed!”
text_esv: Then Isaac trembled very violently and said, “Who was it then that hunted game and brought it to me, and I ate it all before you came, and I have blessed him? Yes, and he shall be blessed.”
text_nlt: Isaac began to tremble uncontrollably and said, “Then who just served me wild game? I have already eaten it, and I blessed him just before you came. And yes, that blessing must stand!”
text_msg: Isaac started to tremble, shaking violently. He said, "Then who hunted game and brought it to me? I finished the meal just now, before you walked in. And I blessed him—he's blessed for good!"
text_nasb: Then Isaac trembled violently, and said, 'Who was he then that hunted game and brought [it] to me, so that I ate of all [of it] before you came, and blessed him? Yes, and he shall be blessed.'
context: Genesis 27 narrates a pivotal moment in the patriarchal narrative: Isaac's impending death and the blessing intended for his firstborn, Esau. Understanding this verse requires acknowledging the cultural significance of birthright and blessings in ancient Near Eastern societies. The birthright conferred specific privileges, including inheritance and leadership within the family. Blessings, particularly paternal blessings, were viewed as powerful declarations that influenced the recipient's destiny and well-being. Isaac, nearing the end of his life and partially blind, intended to bestow this blessing upon Esau, his favorite son, who was a skilled hunter and man of the field. This preference clashed with God's earlier declaration that the younger son, Jacob, would rule over the elder (Genesis 25:23). Rebekah, favoring Jacob and knowing of God's prophecy, orchestrated a deception. She and Jacob conspired to trick Isaac into blessing Jacob instead of Esau. This involved Jacob impersonating Esau, even going so far as to wear Esau's clothes and cover his arms with goatskins to mimic Esau's hairy skin. The venison, specifically mentioned, was part of the ritual. The preparation and consumption of the venison signified Isaac's acknowledgment of Esau's provision and fitness to receive the blessing. This scene unfolds against a backdrop of familial favoritism, divine prophecy, and calculated deception, highlighting the complex dynamics of the patriarchal family and the consequences of their actions. The 'trembling exceedingly' reflects not merely physical fear but a profound realization of having been deceived and the irreversible nature of the blessing he had bestowed.
meaning: Isaac's reaction, described as 'trembling exceedingly,' underscores the gravity of the situation. The phrase suggests a physical and emotional shock, a deep unsettling that stemmed from several realizations. Firstly, Isaac realizes he has been utterly deceived. He recognizes the voice, the touch, and the taste of the venison all pointed to Esau, yet it was Jacob. This exposes his own vulnerability and the depth of the deception. Secondly, he understands the irrevocability of the blessing. In the ancient world, blessings, especially those bestowed by a patriarch, were considered binding and powerful declarations. Isaac's words, 'I have blessed him? Yea, and he shall be blessed,' confirm that the blessing has been spoken and cannot be taken back. This highlights the importance of words and the responsibility attached to them. Thirdly, Isaac's trembling might reflect a dawning awareness of God's will. Although he favored Esau, God had declared that Jacob would rule. The deception, though morally questionable, served to fulfill God's prophetic word. This raises questions about the relationship between human actions and divine sovereignty. While Isaac intended to bless Esau, God's plan was for Jacob to receive the blessing. The verse reveals the limitations of human agency in the face of God's predetermined purpose. The blessing itself carries theological weight. It signified not only material prosperity but also spiritual leadership and covenantal promises. By blessing Jacob, Isaac inadvertently aligned himself with God's plan, even though he initially intended to do otherwise. The blessing's impact would extend far beyond Jacob's lifetime, shaping the destiny of his descendants and the nation of Israel.
application: Genesis 27:33 offers several practical lessons for modern believers. Firstly, it serves as a warning against deception. Jacob and Rebekah's actions, while seemingly effective in securing the blessing, were morally wrong and had long-lasting consequences within the family. We should strive for honesty and integrity in all our dealings, even when faced with difficult choices. The ends do not justify the means. Secondly, it challenges us to examine our own biases and favoritism. Isaac's preference for Esau blinded him to God's plan and made him vulnerable to deception. We should be aware of our own tendencies to favor certain people or things and seek God's guidance in making fair and just decisions. This applies to our relationships with family, friends, and colleagues. Thirdly, it underscores the importance of discernment. Isaac was deceived because he relied on his senses rather than seeking God's wisdom. We should cultivate spiritual discernment through prayer, Bible study, and wise counsel, allowing the Holy Spirit to guide our understanding and decisions. Don't rely solely on your own understanding. Fourthly, it reminds us of the power of our words. Isaac's blessing, once spoken, could not be revoked. We should be mindful of the words we speak, recognizing that they have the power to build up or tear down, to bless or curse. Choose words that are encouraging, truthful, and edifying. Finally, it highlights the sovereignty of God. Even in the midst of human deceit and flawed choices, God's plan prevailed. We can trust that God is working all things together for good, even when we don't understand his ways. This doesn't excuse sinful behavior, but it offers comfort and assurance in the face of uncertainty. Surrender to His will and trust in His divine plan, even when circumstances seem chaotic or unfair.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive us for the times we have been deceitful, either actively or passively. Help us to cultivate honesty and integrity in all our relationships. Grant us discernment to see through deception and to make wise choices that honor you. Help us to be mindful of the power of our words, choosing to speak life and encouragement to those around us. We confess our biases and favoritism and ask for your guidance in treating everyone with fairness and love. Remind us of your sovereignty and your unwavering faithfulness, even when we don't understand your ways. Give us peace and trust in your divine plan, knowing that you are working all things together for good. We ask for a heart that is open to your will, even when it differs from our own desires. Lead us in truth and guide us in your wisdom. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Isaac's advanced age and failing eyesight contributed to his deception. Also, his strong preference for Esau likely clouded his judgment, making him more susceptible to believing what he wanted to be true, rather than being objective. He relied on sensory input and his own desires.
faqs.question: Q1: Why was Isaac so easily deceived, being a patriarch and presumably wise?

faqs.answer: Absolutely not. While God ultimately used Jacob's deception to fulfill His purposes, it doesn't condone the act itself. Deception is consistently condemned in Scripture, and Jacob faced consequences for his actions. God can use sinful acts for good, but that does not make the sin right.
faqs.question: Q2: Does this passage suggest that it's okay to lie if it fulfills God's plan?

faqs.answer: The blessing involved both material and spiritual promises. It included prosperity, dominion over others (specifically, in this case, Esau), and ultimately, a connection to the Abrahamic covenant. Receiving this blessing was seen as securing God's favor and guaranteeing a prosperous future for descendants.
faqs.question: Q3: What were the specific components of the blessing that made it so valuable?

faqs.answer: Rebekah's actions highlight a lack of faith and patience. She likely feared Isaac would not follow God's plan and took matters into her own hands. Her impatience led to a flawed plan, relying on her own strength instead of fully trusting God's timing and method.
faqs.question: Q4: Why didn't Rebekah trust that God would fulfill his promise to Jacob without resorting to trickery?

faqs.answer: Isaac's trembling could indicate a realization that he had been trying to thwart God's predetermined plan. He may have sensed that despite his intentions, divine sovereignty had prevailed, and God's will was being accomplished through Jacob. It's a moment of profound recognition.
